and zero would produce a zero a one and a one would also produce a zero but a zero and a one or a one and a zero would
produce a one and that's it that is your encrypted message and in fact exor is
reversible so what you can do is you can take encrypted message the cipher text and you can repeat the same procedure uh
between the the cipher text and the key and you will be able to recover the original message now if you fulfill certain
prerequisites we can actually mathematically prove that this technique is UN unbreakable so these are the pre

state or to to an to a state of an atom right and the atom had two observable States and if the atom was found to be

k0o and K1 and they together they form the So-Cal Z bases because they are
aligned with the Z axis through the block sphere however there's nothing in quantum mechanics that forces us to use
the states K zero and K 1 when working with a qbit in fact quantum mechanics
only tells us you only can have two observable States at once but doesn't
tell us which states this should be and in fact mathematically speaking any two any two uh points that we find opposite
from each other on the Block sphere the so- called antipodal points can be connected with through with the center
of the sphere using vectors and they would form a valid basis and um uh and
and effective via basis is again it's a pair of observable States so so the basis that is very often used is this x
bases because it aligns with the x axis through the the center of the the block
sphere and it consists of the states that are typically called K plus and K minus now we cannot call these states K
zero or k one because they are mathematically different so the vector is different because the mathematics is
like flipped on its side now right but in this case these states become the
observable States in a cubit and the states K 0 and K 1 are no longer observable because we still have only
two observable States we have to map them to beat 0o and beat one of course and the concept of the superposition is
still there right so every other state except this K plus and C minus that is a
superposition State including the state K 0 and K 1 which previously were observable now they are not because we
can only observe now K plus and K minus if this doesn't make sense then the way you can think about this is that the
choice of Bas is a different way of encoding and decoding information in and out of cubits so we can encode a zero
into a cubit by creating a state C zero or by creating a state C plus and we can encode a one into a cubit by creating a
state K 1 or k minus right and if we put them side by side something very
interesting emerges because if you consider a state K zero like this right
if we have a cubit that is really in a state K zero and I try to observe this Cubit using the Z uh the Z basis then I
will get a deterministic result because the Cubit will always uh tell me that yes thank you for observing me I am
really in state C zero right but if the cubid is in a state C zero and I try to observe it using the X basis well this
is a state that is impossible to be observed in the X Bas it's a superposition state so what I will get
as a result of such an observation I can only get K plus or C minus those are the only two things that are observable so
what I will get is a random result I will randomly get this or that right and
not only that the way you can picture this is that if the arrow was pointing here upwards then by observing the cubit
in the wrong Bas oops in the wrong basis effectively the arrow moves to one of
the observable State either cat Plus or k minus so not only we got a random result we destroyed the original state
and this is the key thing here if we observe in the wrong basis we are going to destroy information right and this is
very very power powerful concept because the choice of bases in in a cubit allows us to encode information in a very
specific way you will only be able to read this information if you know the encoding that was used in the first
place if you don't you will not only get the random result you will destroy the information and it's like security that
is built into the very fabric of our reality you have one shot at reading the information and if you uh if you choose
the wrong basis you will destroy the information and this is something that we call entropic uncertainty relation
and this is really at the heart of quantum cryptography and there's another interesting consequence of that and that
is if you don't know the encoding of a cubit you will not be able to make a copy of it now there's a beautiful
mathematical proof for that but just using Common Sense what is the act of copying if I have something here and I'd
like to copy it over here what do I have to do well I have to take the source thing and accumulate all the possible
information about this thing and use that information to reconstruct this thing at the Target location but with a cubit in order to
get any information about the Cubit I have to observe it but I cannot observe it if I don't know the basis because
otherwise I will destroy it right so from that perspective it's impossible and in 1984 Charlie Bennett and Jil
brart published a a paper that used exactly this principle to um uh develop
the first Quantum key distribution protocol and with a Quantum key distribution what we can do is we can
actually exchange a secret in a secure way over a channel that is insecure and this is
like is just not logical it's not a logical statement but this is thanks to this effect that we just
discussed so here's how it works so Alice generates a long sequence of random bits and uh if if she wants uh to
establish a 256bit key with Bob she will have to generate four times as many uh
beats so she has to generate 1,24 random bits we will see in a moment why this is the case she then proceeds
to encode those into Q bits by randomly switching between the Z and the X basis so a zero in the Z basis State C zero a
zero in the X basis State C plus and so on right two different beats but four different Quantum states she then sends
those cuits over um a Quantum communication Network some sort of an optical link for example to Bob and this
channel doesn't have to be secure so they don't have to have a sort of a a TLS connection here right and then Bob
proceeds to decode those cubits but he doesn't know how to decode them because he doesn't know which bases Alice chose
so what he does is he also randomly switches between the Z and X bases and next thing Alice and
Bob communicate over a public Channel and compare the bases that they use they keep the values secret just the bases
and they throw away all the values for which they used incompatible bases but for where they use the same bases to
encode and decode a bit in and out of qbit they should now have the same bit value right so they should now have a
shared key in their possession now statistically speaking because there are two bases bul will be correct in about
half of the cases so they would throw away half of the beats and half of the beats are left so if they started with
10,24 they are now down to 512 right so they have to make sure that there was no
EES dropper on this communication Channel because we said that this channel is insecure but as it turns out
the attacker is very limited in terms of what the attack could do here because the only thing that attacker can do is
to try to copy the cuits but to copy the cubits the attacker has to observe them but if the attacker doesn't know the
encoding basis well the attacker cannot make a copy right this is forbidden by the law of quantum mechanics so the only
thing the attacker can do is to also guess the bases right and that would inevitably destroy some of the original
information that Alice encoded so what Alice and Bob can then do is they take
half of the remaining bits so they had 512 so now they take 256 bits they
reveal them to to each other and if they find any mismatches it means that there was an e dropper that actually destroyed
some of the original information that Alice encoded and that's how they can detect an attacker so in other words
they are always able to know if somebody read that information and this is tremendously powerful right and it all
